changing if we are to look at a history

I had to scribble on you could see all

of things with codasyl and network
network databases and then what you can
see in the middle is even about the
1970s we started to get the relational

and then you've got Oracle version 2 now
Oracle version 2 apparently a Larry
Larry Ellison didn't believe a version 1

version 1 version 2 and then after that
you've got all of the relational

server etc and then the open source

my sequel and then what has happened
that is from 1970 up until mid 2000s a
stable relational story and then there
was an explosion of databases that have

and these are databases like Cassandra
react our own dynamodb MongoDB and so on
there are now giving you a huge choice
of how you can actually deploy databases
to for your applications
so looking at how people do traditional
applications today what are the types of
things that you would typically do well
you would have a client here an
application tier and then a database
tier and in that database you would say
we're going to put everything in there
right doesn't matter what it is it's
going to be the the Swiss Army knife
with all of these different data points
in there where there's key value whether
it's log files transactions analytics
anything goes in that relational
database that was the mantra of how you
build applications what we're saying is
that there's a better way of doing that
and what you want to be able to do is
say right well this is clearly a caching
use case or this is a no sequel use case
I'm going to use a specific database to
solve that specific component or part of
the application so that means if you
want to do logging then don't put that
data in the database put that into
something like our s3 service if you're
going to do searching don't expect the
relational system to do that put that
into something like elastic search and
if you're going to do caching put that
into something like Redis running on our
managed service ElastiCache so really
try and architect your applications to
use the right data store for the
particular job so what are the data
bases that we have on offer or data
stores that you can use to build your
applications well the first one here is
on the relational side we have Amazon
Aurora and Amazon RDS and inside that
managed service we have different
flavors so Aurora supports my sequel and
Postgres and then on RDS we have my
sequel and Postgres Community Edition we
have Oracle sequel server and Maria DB
as well so those are all compiled of
that particular managed service then
when you move to key value data the next
one is dynamo DB so this is a huge
scalable highly available highly durable
database operating in a no sequel way
where you can do key value data and then
for document we also support JSON
documents in dynamo DB as well and then
on the next one we have a database in
preview called net
which allows you to actually have a
graphing model for storing your data so
this is very good when you have very
complex relationships and data
associated with those relationships if
you're thinking in a relational model
when you have a kind of clear-cut case
for a graph database if you're doing
complex joins on the same table with
other bit tables as well and you're
constantly referencing that same object
and doing circular references that's
kind of telling you that there's a graph
type of relationship there then if
you're looking for in memory operations
we have ElastiCache which supports
memcache and Redis and then finally on
the right hand side for search we have
Amazon's own elastic search service so
these are all managed services in our
database portfolio that you can build
solutions with today so that's the
database market is changing right from
that singular database in the relational
world to be able to use all these
different databases for your application
now what's also changing is application
architecture so what's actually
happening this is a kind of ball of

with the micro services so Amazon itself

based on the service orientated
architecture concept and you connect to
this through simple API so over HTTP and
it's a single purpose what this actual
micro service does is it lives and
breathes to deliver a particular service
and then you connect all of those up to
build applications which is what this
big blob looks like so if you're
thinking about what you do today and how
this has evolved is you probably still
have many monolithic applications and
when you take those monolithic

solar which is what has been around you
know since the the 2000s have you liked
then that was kind of coarse grain but
micro services take that to the next
level where we're really getting down to
fine grained services and pulling all of
those together to create applications
now when you move
to microservices you will see some
people talk about there's a couple of
things that are really found
foundational ideas around them one is
that you should have a plot a polyglot
ecosystem that is for each micro-service
you should decide what is the best
technology for that particular micro
service you could even use mixtures of
technology inside that micro service
whereas traditionally people have
standardized on say a java and oracle
stack or a dotnet and sequel server
stack now for each micro service you can
use what's the right data store for that
particular micro source and indeed for a
given micro service you may have
multiple data stores to deliver that
particular service
now that doesn't lend itself very well
to commercial databases because what's
going to happen is if you split your

a licensing cost blowout
so what we're tending to find is that
customers are now saying when we move to

availability durability and support and

we introduced 16 terabytes of storage

that are now coming in to AWS whether

some of them are sources and some of

Postgres I recall my sequel sequel

we also have the schema conversion tool
so remember I said that the database

that it does

at that point that destination database

hey the database migration service
that's what it says on the tin let's use

remember that this is the actual process
so how does DMS work you've got on your
left-hand side here a source database
running on-premise today on the right
hand side you've got AWS with your nice
empty database already created by the
schema conversion tool you've got a VPN
and you've got your application users
connecting to the original environment
what we're going to do now is we're
going to actually create a replication
instance so this is what DMS runs on and
then we're going to connect the source
and the target once we've connected the
source and the target then we need to
select the tables the schemas or perhaps
the whole database to migrate across and
once we've done that then we're going to

happen while your application is still
running on premise and now at this point
everything is basically caught up you're
going to have to suspend activity on the
primary system wait make sure
everything's caught up on the other side
which should hopefully only be a few
seconds and then you simply flip
environment over to AWS so now we've

reasonably intensive it's going to take
